docs.title: 01 – Preprocessing Data

docs.title: 01 – Preprocessing Data¶
docs.text:
This notebook performs the following steps:

  1. Download data
  2. (Optional) Combine instance segmentation masks from silver and gold ground truth
  3. Save detections into a CSV file
  4. Convert image and label data to Zarr format
  5. Compute tracking accuracy metrics with only d(position) as edge cost

docs.title: Download Data¶
docs.text: The raw .tif images are first downloaded to the directory specified by data_dir.

docs.title: Export Detection Data to CSV¶
docs.text:
Next, we generate a single CSV file containing the locations of all detected instances. Each detection is assigned a unique ID.

The CSV includes the following columns: sequence, id, t, [z], y, x, parent_id, original_id

Note: The man_track_file_names input is optional. It is used here solely for evaluation purposes (e.g., assigning the values in the parent_id column), and is not required for model training or for solving the ILP.

docs.title: Convert Data to Zarr Format¶
docs.text:
Then, we convert the data into a single Zarr file. This file contains one group for each sequence in the dataset.

Within each sequence group, you'll find two datasets:

  • img – the raw image data
  • mask – the corresponding instance segmentation masks All the masks will be relabeled to ensure unique instance IDs across the entire dataset.

docs.title: Compute Tracking Performance using only d(position) as edge cost¶
docs.text: Finally, to understand how well we perform using only position as a feature, we compute the tracking performance using only d(position) as edge cost. Please ensure gurobi is installed for a faster solving experience.

docs.title: 02 - Train auto-encoder model.
docs.text:

docs.title: 02 - Train auto-encoder model.¶
docs.text:
This notebook performs the following steps:

  1. Train an autoencoder model Image crops centered on detections are extracted from the raw dataset and used to train the model. You can choose between:
  • A standard autoencoder, trained using a reconstruction loss to reproduce the input crops.
  • A variational autoencoder (VAE), trained using a combination of negative log-likelihood and KL divergence loss.
  1. Infer embeddings using the trained encoder
  • For a standard autoencoder, the encoder’s output is directly used as the embedding.
  • For a variational autoencoder, the posterior mean is used as the embedding representation.

docs.title: Create an iterable, train dataset.¶
docs.text: It samples a random row from the detections file and extracts the image crop at that position.

docs.title: Infer embeddings¶
docs.text: Next, we use the trained model weights to infer the embeddings for each detection in the dataset.

docs.title: Compute Tracking Performance using d(position) and d(embedding) as edge costs.¶
docs.text: Please ensure gurobi is installed for a faster solving experience.

docs.title: 03 - Train trackastra model with attrackt unsupervised loss.
docs.text:
In [1]: Copied!

docs.title: 03 - Train trackastra model with attrackt unsupervised loss.¶
docs.text: This notebook uses the zarr container (created in the first notebook) and the embeddings (exported to a csv in the second notebook) to train a trackastra model with the attrackt unsupervised loss.

docs.title: Compute Tracking Performance using d(position) and predicted associations as edge costs.¶
docs.text: Please ensure gurobi is installed for a faster solving experience.

docs.title: Sort the nodes using an uncertainty measure.¶
04 - Fine-tune pre-trained trackastra model with sparse supervision.
docs.text:
In [1]: Copied!

docs.title: 04 - Fine-tune pre-trained trackastra model with sparse supervision.¶
docs.text: This notebook uses the zarr container (created in the first notebook), the embeddings (exported to a csv in the second notebook), and the model trained with unsupervised loss (in the third notebook) to fine-tune the model weights with GT supervision.

docs.title: Create train and val unsupervised datasets¶
Compute Tracking Performance using d(position) and predicted associations as edge costs.¶
docs.text: Please ensure gurobi is installed for a faster solving experience.

docs.title: 01 – Preprocessing Data
docs.text:

docs.title: 01 – Preprocessing Data¶
docs.text:
This notebook performs the following steps:

  1. Download data
  2. (Optional) Combine instance segmentation masks from silver and gold ground truth
  3. Save detections into a CSV file
  4. Convert image and label data to Zarr format
  5. Compute tracking accuracy metrics with only d(position) as edge cost

docs.title: Download Data¶
docs.text: The raw .tif images are first downloaded to the directory specified by data_dir.

docs.title: (Optional) Merge Silver and Gold Segmentation Masks¶
docs.text:
In this optional step, we combine the segmentation masks from the silver and gold ground truth datasets.

You can skip this step if:

  • Your masks are already dense and gold-standard, or
  • You do not have silver ground truth data available.

Note: This step will overwrite the contents of 01_GT/TRA and 02_GT/TRA with the newly merged masks.

docs.title: Export Detection Data to CSV¶
docs.text:
Next, we generate a single CSV file containing the locations of all detected instances. Each detection is assigned a unique ID.

The CSV includes the following columns: sequence, id, t, [z], y, x, parent_id, original_id

Note: The man_track_file_names input is optional. It is used here solely for evaluation purposes (e.g., assigning the values in the parent_id column), and is not required for model training or for solving the ILP.

docs.title: Convert Data to Zarr Format¶
docs.text:
Then, we convert the data into a single Zarr file. This file contains one group for each sequence in the dataset.

Within each sequence group, you'll find two datasets:

  • img – the raw image data
  • mask – the corresponding instance segmentation masks All the masks will be relabeled to ensure unique instance IDs across the entire dataset.

docs.title: Compute Tracking Performance using only d(position) as edge cost¶
docs.text: Finally, to understand how well we perform using only position as a feature, we compute the tracking performance using only d(position) as edge cost. Please ensure gurobi is installed for a faster solving experience.

docs.title: 02 - Train auto-encoder model.
docs.text:

docs.title: 02 - Train auto-encoder model.¶
docs.text:
This notebook performs the following steps:

  1. Train an autoencoder model Image crops centered on detections are extracted from the raw dataset and used to train the model. You can choose between:
  • A standard autoencoder, trained using a reconstruction loss to reproduce the input crops.
  • A variational autoencoder (VAE), trained using a combination of negative log-likelihood and KL divergence loss.
  1. Infer embeddings using the trained encoder
  • For a standard autoencoder, the encoder’s output is directly used as the embedding.
  • For a variational autoencoder, the posterior mean is used as the embedding representation.

docs.title: Create an iterable, train dataset.¶
docs.text: It samples a random row from the detections file and extracts the image crop at that position.

docs.title: Infer embeddings¶
docs.text: Next, we use the trained model weights to infer the embeddings for each detection in the dataset.

docs.title: Compute Tracking Performance using d(position) and d(embedding) as edge costs.¶
docs.text: Please ensure gurobi is installed for a faster solving experience.

docs.title: 03 - Train trackastra model with attrackt unsupervised loss.

docs.title: 03 - Train trackastra model with attrackt unsupervised loss.¶
docs.text: This notebook uses the zarr container (created in the first notebook) and the embeddings (exported to a csv in the second notebook) to train a trackastra model with the attrackt unsupervised loss.

docs.title: Compute Tracking Performance using d(position) and predicted associations as edge costs.¶
docs.text: Please ensure gurobi is installed for a faster solving experience.

docs.title: Sort the nodes using an uncertainty measure.¶
04 - Fine-tune pre-trained trackastra model with sparse supervision.

docs.title: 04 - Fine-tune pre-trained trackastra model with sparse supervision.¶
docs.text: This notebook uses the zarr container (created in the first notebook), the embeddings (exported to a csv in the second notebook), and the model trained with unsupervised loss (in the third notebook) to fine-tune the model weights with GT supervision.

docs.title: Create train and val unsupervised datasets¶
Compute Tracking Performance using d(position) and predicted associations as edge costs.¶
docs.text: Please ensure gurobi is installed for a faster solving experience.
